        <div class="blog-post">
         <div class="blog-heading">
          <h1>
           5 Stats You Need to Know about Millennials and How to Market to Them
          </h1>
         </div>
         <div class="blog-meta meta-detailed">
          <div class="author-image">
           <a href="https://www.hudsonhorizons.com/blog/author/samanthapena">
            <img alt="" src="/pub/blogauthor/20140627112229_20140319144747_sam.png"/>
           </a>
          </div>
          <div class="meta-right">
           <p class="author">
            <a href="https://www.hudsonhorizons.com/blog/author/samanthapena">
             Samantha Pena
            </a>
           </p>
           <p class="date">
            January 13, 2015
           </p>
          </div>
          <!-- end of meta-right -->
         </div>
         <!-- end of blog-meta -->
         <div class="blog-image blog-single-image flexFill">
          <img alt="5 Stats You Need to Know about Millennials and How to Market to Them " src="/pub/blogimages/20150113125813_millennial.jpg"/>
         </div>
         <!-- end of blog-image -->
         <div class="blog-text">
          <p>
           Lets get real for a second and talk about millennials. More specifically, lets talk about how you can
           <em>
            market
           </em>
           to millennials, because theyre quite tricky to understand and elusive to reach.
          </p>
          <p>
           Born between 1981 and 2000, they grew up just as the digital world was burgeoning. Theyre tech-savvy and embrace social media, and regardless of whether they do or dont have money, theyre spending 
           <em>
            a lot
           </em>
           .
          </p>
          <p>
           Oh yeah  and theyre picky about the products they buy and the brands they follow. You can blast ads at them all day long to no avail. They wont pay attention unless they see it at the right time and the right place.
          </p>
          <p>
           As part of the millennial generation myself, I can understand the struggles of most advertisers: how
           <em>
            do
           </em>
           you reach millennials when its hard to pin down who they are, where they go, and what they like?
          </p>
          <p>
           Luckily, a
           <a href="http://www.adweek.com/news/technology/here-everything-you-need-know-about-millennial-consumer-159139" target="_blank">
            study
           </a>
           was done to understand millennials.
          </p>
          <p>
           Here are 5 important stats about millennials from the study that you need to know and tips on how you could use this information to better market to them.
          </p>
          <h2>
           <strong>
            68% are completely unfazed by celebrity endorsements or star-studded ads
           </strong>
          </h2>
          <p>
           Back then, getting a celebrity to publicly support your product was akin to hitting the jackpot, mostly because the sales and renown you received was well worth the amount you paid for the endorsement.
          </p>
          <p>
           However, times have since changed.
          </p>
          <p>
           Though its still nice to have a celebrity endorse your brand, its not wholly necessary. Our current startup culture, in addition to social media, have leveled the marketing playground, making it easier for smaller brands to contend with big corporations for the heart  and wallets  of the current generation.
          </p>
          <p>
           From brands to cats, anyone can gain popularity on the Internet nowadays. All you really need is a brilliant idea and social media to spread the word.
          </p>
          <p>
           Just take a look at GoldieBlox. It made its debut on Kickstarter in 2012, and without a celebrity endorsement or really any traditional marketing, it not only managed to raise double its fundraising goal but also attracted
           <em>
            a lot
           </em>
           of press.
          </p>
          <p>
           How? Well, with a brilliant idea, brought to life in one viral YouTube video.
          </p>
          <p>
           <object data="//www.youtube.com/v/IIGyVa5Xftw&amp;ab=en_US" height="315" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="560">
            <param name="allowFullScreen" value="true">
            </param>
            <param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always">
            </param>
            <param name="src" value="//www.youtube.com/v/IIGyVa5Xftw&amp;ab=en_US">
            </param>
            <param name="allowfullscreen" value="true">
            </param>
           </object>
          </p>
          <p>
           Now, GoldieBlox is competing with Legos to win over the female demographic. Not too shabby for a startup, and GoldieBlox is just one example. There are many other startups that have gained immense popularity, not because of a celeb endorsement or a huge advertising budget but as a result of an
           <a href="http://www.hudsonhorizons.com/digital-marketing/social-media-marketing" target="_blank">
            awesome social media marketing campaign
           </a>
           .
          </p>
          <h2>
           <strong>
            18% live at home and are financially dependent on their parents
           </strong>
          </h2>
          <p>
           As greater importance is placed on a university degree, coupled with the rising cost of living and of education, many millennials are burdened with a lot of debt and end up moving back home after graduation.
          </p>
          <p>
           However, that doesnt mean that theyre not spending.
          </p>
          <p>
           The fact that 55% believe their personal financial situation will improve within a year shows that millennials are optimistic about the future. Theyre willing to spend, but only if its the right price and the right brand.
          </p>
          <p>
           The proliferation of e-commerce marketplaces like Amazon, with their offers of big discounts and free shipping, have made the millennial generation more hesitant of buying products at full-price. Loyalty to brands only extends as far as the price goes; if they can find a different brand with the same product, more likely than not, theyll go with that brand.
          </p>
          <p>
           Therefore, offering discounts and loyalty programs are great ways to keep customers coming back for more.
          </p>
          <h2>
           <strong>
            71% browse online but do their actual shopping offline
           </strong>
          </h2>
          <p>
           If youre a brick-and-mortar business that is still operating purely offline, then youre missing out on a
           <em>
            huge
           </em>
           demographic.
          </p>
          <p>
           Millennials
           <em>
            rely
           </em>
           on technology and the Internet for pretty much everything. With an estimated
           <a href="http://www.forbes.com/sites/micahsolomon/2014/12/29/5-traits-that-define-the-80-million-millennial-customers-coming-your-way/" target="_blank">
            80 million consumers
           </a>
           in this generation who are expected to spend $200 billion
           <em>
            annually
           </em>
           by 2017, building an online presence in this day and age is absolutely integral if you want a chance at selling to these millennials.
          </p>
          <p>
           Let me give you an example. I recently visited Washington D.C. over the holidays. Never having visited D.C. before, I looked to Yelp reviews and local listings on Google Maps to give me the scoop on the best restaurants, bars, and museums in D.C.
          </p>
          <p>
           <img alt="google local results example" src="/pub/images/dc1.jpg"/>
           <img alt="google local results example" src="/pub/images/dc2.jpg"/>
          </p>
          <p>
           Would I have found these places if they didnt have an online presence? Probably not. In fact, call me a snob, but I probably would have dismissed them as automatically bad if they
           <em>
            werent
           </em>
           online. However, the information I found online ultimately persuaded me to visit the places I did.
          </p>
          <p>
           Remember that millennials grew up in the digital age, so they expect technology to simply work with little hassle on their part. Therefore, having an optimized online presence is the key to getting more foot traffic to your business.
          </p>
          <p>
           Also, as more consumers do their research online before purchasing, its important to establish a cross-channel brand presence on
           <a href="http://www.hudsonhorizons.com/design/web-design" target="_blank">
            web
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="http://www.hudsonhorizons.com/development/mobile" target="_blank">
            mobile
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="http://www.hudsonhorizons.com/digital-marketing/social-media-marketing" target="_blank">
            social
           </a>
           , and
           <a href="http://www.hudsonhorizons.com/digital-marketing/sem" target="_blank">
            search
           </a>
           . This way, no matter where consumers are looking online, your brand dominates their digital space.
          </p>
          <h2>
           <strong>
            60% said the consumer experience should be consistent across online, store, and mobile
           </strong>
          </h2>
          <p>
           In a similar vein, even though businesses
           <em>
            need
           </em>
           to be online, it doesnt mean you should ignore everything offline either. In fact, online and offline strategies must work in tandem, nurturing consumers into becoming loyal customers. An integrated strategy can accomplish this.
          </p>
          <p>
           Chipotles scarecrow campaign is a wildly successful example of this type of integrated brand strategy. They utilized online and offline strategies to promote their brand philosophy, generating both interest and sales. In one campaign, they created the following pieces:
          </p>
          <p>
           A microsite
          </p>
          <p>
           <img alt="chipotle scarecrow website" src="/pub/images/scarecrow_web.png"/>
          </p>
          <p>
           A video
          </p>
          <p>
           <object data="//www.youtube.com/v/lUtnas5ScSE&amp;ab=en_US" height="315" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="560">
            <param name="allowFullScreen" value="true">
            </param>
            <param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always">
            </param>
            <param name="src" value="//www.youtube.com/v/lUtnas5ScSE&amp;ab=en_US">
            </param>
            <param name="allowfullscreen" value="true">
            </param>
           </object>
          </p>
          <p>
           A mobile app game
          </p>
          <p>
           <img alt="chipotle scarecrow app game" src="/pub/images/scarecrow_app.jpg"/>
          </p>
          <p>
           Social media promotions
          </p>
          <p>
           <img alt="chipotle scarecrow social updates" src="/pub/images/scarecrow_social2.png"/>
          </p>
          <p>
           And last, but most certainly not least, actual people coming in and buying their food with their buy-one, get-one free coupon deals when you complete certain levels in the game.
          </p>
          <p>
           Aside from now really wanting a burrito, what did we learn from this campaign?
          </p>
          <p>
           For one thing, they artfully conveyed the one thing about their brand that makes them unique  their brand story. Do a bit of soul searching and ask yourself this: what is it about your brand that makes you
           <em>
            different
           </em>
           from your competition and
           <em>
            indispensable
           </em>
           to your customers?
           <em>
            Thats
           </em>
           your marketing sweet spot.
          </p>
          <p>
           The second lesson from the scarecrow campaign is the implementation of the campaign. Even though the campaign had a lot of moving pieces, they all complemented one another and added to the greater whole, which is their brand. This is integrated marketing at its finest: creating a unified brand presence across all channels.
          </p>
          <h2>
           <strong>
            58% want to have full control over how they engage with brands
           </strong>
          </h2>
          <p>
           As consumers become more empowered, brands must understand that their role in the business/consumer relationship must shift to adapt to their customers changing desires.
          </p>
          <p>
           Consumers simply dont want to be bombarded by ad after ad. Instead, they want to take a more active role in shaping their brand experience.
          </p>
          <p>
           Think about GoPro. Most, if not all, of their ads are consumer-driven, showing people all the cool and memorable things their customers capture with their product. Their latest video is just one example of this.
          </p>
          <p>
           <object data="//www.youtube.com/v/r3q3ZC5fcnY&amp;ab=en_US" height="315" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="560">
            <param name="allowFullScreen" value="true">
            </param>
            <param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always">
            </param>
            <param name="src" value="//www.youtube.com/v/r3q3ZC5fcnY&amp;ab=en_US">
            </param>
            <param name="allowfullscreen" value="true">
            </param>
           </object>
          </p>
          <p>
           With their slogans Be a Hero and Capture + share your world, they show that the customers not only own the brand  they
           <em>
            are
           </em>
           the brand.
          </p>
          <p>
           Therefore, allowing consumers to shape your brand not only fosters loyalty but also encourages them to share their experiences on social media, which has the added benefit of essentially being free advertising.
          </p>
          <h2>
           <strong>
            Whats your marketing plan for millennials?
           </strong>
          </h2>
          <p>
           In the end, a good marketing campaign is all about understanding your audience and having the ability to deliver what they want. Isn't it time you give it to them?
          </p>

         <!-- end of blog-text -->
         <div class="blog-meta meta-detailed">

           <a href="https://www.hudsonhorizons.com/blog/author/samanthapena">
            <img alt="Samantha Pena" src="/pub/blogauthor/20140627112229_20140319144747_sam.png"/>
           </a>
          </div>
          <div class="meta-right">
           <p>
            This article was published by
            <a href="https://www.hudsonhorizons.com/blog/author/samanthapena">
             Samantha Pena
            </a>
            .
           </p>
          </div>
          <!-- end of meta-right -->
          <div class="bio-container">
           <p>
            Samantha Pena is a Content Strategist at Hudson. Hermain focus and passion is creating amazing content that is accurate, up-to-date, and (most importantly) interesting. Her main obsessions are social media, trending topics, and anything web-related. When she has the time, she likes to read, write, and travel. Follow her on
